race.name: Gravel and Granite
race.tagline: Gravel and Granite. 65 miles of gravel through Tenterfield.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Australian mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Australian event. Mountain terrain with remote access, moderate costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel and Granite is a local event in NSW—mountain terrain with significant elevation. The Australian mountains are scenic, but the very small field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Australian mountain gravel race. Worth it for NSW/Australian riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to NSW—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Australian races: Gravel Gong, Dirty Gravel.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Tenterfield has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Tenterfield has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: Start location at 73 Manners Street with showground camping, but course redesign after a sabbatical year creates uncertainty. Organizers moved 2026 dates to May specifically because "2026 GnG will be held in May, to make the most of the cooler weather," indicating previous timing was problematic. Complete route overhaul happened because "many of the roads that we have used in previous years are now sealed."

length.explanation: At 65 miles through NSW granite country, riders face sustained challenges without survival scenarios. Jacob learned pacing discipline on early climbs: "I had to keep reminding myself not to push too hard on this climb, there was still an entire course to finish afterwards." Four feed stations at strategic intervals support the distance properly.

technicality.explanation: The Range Rumble features creek crossings and "an absolute wall with grades in excess of 15%" at the 50km crux climb. Surface mix runs 59% gravel including fire tracks and rough service roads through Basket Swamp and Boonoo Boonoo National Parks, designed for what organizers call "Type 2 fun."

elevation.explanation: The 4,500 feet of climbing includes extended ascents and technical descents through national parks. Range Rumble course delivers "about 10km" of climbing at the 50km crux, with wall-grade pitches that matter without requiring mountaineering skills. The granite country terrain provides sustained vertical challenge.

climate.explanation: Jacob rode through active snowfall: "I spent the next 15 minutes grinding in my lowest gear with snow falling off the trees as we ascended," with "muddy and sloppy" conditions creating traction challenges. The May date change specifically targets "cooler weather" after previous timing proved problematic for rider comfort.

altitude.explanation: NSW granite country elevations stay within manageable bands while delivering mountain character. The 4,500 feet total gain indicates significant vertical through Great Dividing Range terrain without alpine complications. Creek crossings and extended climbing occur at modest absolute altitudes.

adventure.explanation: Basket Swamp Bash creek crossing and sweeping national park views deliver backcountry character. The Range Rumble winds through protected granite country where organizers emphasize focus "on the adventure and the landscape around you" rather than pure racing. Creek depths vary with conditions, adding weather-dependent adventure elements.

prestige.explanation: Sixth edition of a regional event where organizers explicitly welcome "gravel bikes, mountain bikes, e-bikes, and adaptive bikes." Caitlin Reid emphasizes it's "organised to be as welcoming as possible to all riders, regardless of their FTP," with prizes only for fastest two per category, confirming participation over competitive depth.

race_quality.explanation: Proper aid station placement every 17-20km with "food, water, and first aid supplies" shows solid organization basics. However, course evolution happened because "many of the roads that we have used in previous years are now sealed," requiring completely new 2025 routes after taking a sabbatical year.

experience.explanation: Race village features "DJs, food trucks, and local beer and wine at the Tenterfield Showgrounds" with Friday night main street festivities. Jacob experienced "lively atmosphere with the live band" and electric dawn start energy, but the event's sabbatical year and complete course overhaul indicate experience consistency challenges.

community.explanation: Jacob felt "the electricity at the dawn start" as "300 riders left under police escort out of downtown Wausau," with family-friendly weekend atmosphere and inclusive philosophy welcoming all bike types. The Saddlers MTB Club organizes this for trail network funding, but required course redesign shows organizational transitions.

field_depth.explanation: Todd Meerdink worried that losing the lead group early would turn "this race would quickly turn into just a group ride," indicating thin competitive depth. The explicit welcome for adaptive bikes and e-bikes alongside traditional categories prioritizes inclusivity over racing field strength in this regional NSW event.

value.explanation: The NSW Government site lists it as 'free' which either means spectating or they're underselling their own race entry fees. If registration is actually cheap, 65 miles of Australian granite country for minimal cash outlay delivers decent bang for buck. Just don't expect premium race services at budget pricing.

expenses.explanation: Multi-bike welcome policy means riders can use existing mountain bikes rather than buying gravel-specific equipment, with Todd Meerdink successfully using 40mm tires on technical sections. Rural Tenterfield location requires travel from major cities, while Todd's Camelback strategy shows self-sufficient riders can minimize aid station dependencies.
